awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
awd_abstract_narration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Eva Fischer

Proposal Number 1608997

This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Dr. Eva K. Fischer is "Maintenance and evolution of parental care in poison frogs." The host institution for this fellowship is Harvard University and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Lauren A. O'Connell.

The goal of the Fellow's research is to identify physiological, neural, and molecular mechanisms that promote parental care within species, as well as those promoting the evolution of alternative parental care strategies across species. To do so, the Fellow is taking advantage of the rich behavioral diversity of South American poison frogs that exhibit maternal care, paternal care, and biparental care. Different parental care behaviors have evolved across many different species, and allow animals to take advantage of novel habitats and thereby contribute to biodiversity. While parental care has long been appreciated as an evolutionary innovation, very little is known about the mechanisms that underlie the maintenance and evolution of parental behaviors. One particular challenge is that parental care is tightly linked with pair bonding in many species, making it difficult to identify mechanisms specifically associated with parental behaviors.  Comparisons across species with different care strategies allow the Fellow to distinguish mechanisms of parental behavior from those of pair bonding in both males and females. Furthermore, the project takes advantage of the fact that male and female poison frogs can reverse their parenting behaviors. For example, female frogs of paternal care species sometimes provide care when males are inexperienced or disappear. Such reversed behavior may be an important precursor for the evolution of alternative parental care strategies. The Fellow is exploring three specific objectives, which are to identify how (1) hormonal changes, (2) neural activity, and (3) brain gene expression patterns, are linked to parenting behavior. Comparing data between males and females, and among both normal and role-reversing species, will uncover fundamental principles governing how parental care is maintained within a species and how diverse parental care strategies evolve across poison frogs and other animals.

The Fellow's training and career development goals are being met through activities that (1) develop poison frogs as a promising system for an independent research program, (2) refine the Fellow's science communication and professional skills, and (3) improve the Fellow's skills as a mentor, both within the university and the community. A major component of the Fellow's work is creating opportunities for scientific learning and creativity for diverse communities. Broadening participation of groups underrepresented in biology is being encouraged through a variety of activities. (1) The Fellow will is expanding the Little Froggers School Program founded by her sponsoring scientist (Dr. O'Connell) in 2012. This program provides live poison frogs to classrooms and utilizes them as a tool for teaching experiment-based science. The Fellow is also providing training and resources to teachers, regularly visiting participating classrooms, and developing web-based resources for teachers and students. These include lesson plans and activities, reading materials, interviews with researchers, a "Frogger Cam" live video stream, and forums for interaction and data sharing between researchers and students as well as among participating classrooms. (2) Through a partnership with the Science Club for Girls, the Fellow is coordinating activities for K-12 students of all ages, including mentorship of two high school research interns per year. The Science Club for Girls is a non-profit that serves students from racial and socio-economic backgrounds underrepresented in STEM fields, thereby providing meaningful scientific experiences for underserved students of all ages. (3) The fellow is mentoring undergraduates conducting independent research projects in the O'Connell Lab. The fellow is partnering with two Harvard Programs to target underrepresented groups, including racial minorities and first generation college students.

por.por_cntn:
Parental care is exhibited across the animal kingdom, from humans, to birds, to frogs, fish, and beetles. The often costly and elaborate behaviors that constitute parental care, and their importance for offspring health and survival are easily observed; however, we know little about the underlying changes in the brain that control the remarkable transition from ambivalence or even aggression to intense care. Moreover, most of what is known about underlying mechanisms of parental care comes from work on maternal care in rodents. Discerning mechanisms universally important for parental care is impossible without work in additional species.

The current project takes advantage of behavioral diversity in closely related species of poison frogs to identify neural mechanisms important for parental care across species and sexes. Parental care in poison frogs involves defense, hydration and cleaning of eggs, and piggy-back style transportation of tadpoles to pools of water when they hatch. In some species mothers regularly visit their tadpoles and lay unfertilized eggs for tadpoles to eat until they complete metamorphosis. While these basic behaviors are the same, species differ in which sex provides care (i.e. care strategy): the father (male uniparental care), the mother (female uniparental care), or both parents (biparental care). By comparing across closely related species that differ in care strategy, we can identify brain regions and molecules universally important for parental care.

            I first identified brain regions that showed increased activity when parents were transporting tadpoles. I found a core set of brain regions active during parental care across species and sexes. Parents providing care had increased brain activity in the hypothalamus and the hippocampus. The hypothalamus regulates a wide range of social behaviors across vertebrates. The importance of the hypothalamus in parental care has been demonstrated if a number of species, and this is the first confirmation of this function in frogs. The hippocampus is a brain region important for memory in general, and spatial memory in particular, across vertebrates. In poison frogs, activation of this brain region may be especially important for remembering the location of and navigating back to pools of water to deposit tadpoles.

            Focusing on these two core brain regions, I next identified changes in gene expression specifically in neurons active during tadpole transport. I found significant changes in a number of genes with known roles in social behavior, including hormone receptors and neuropeptide signaling molecules. In addition, I found changes in genes traditionally associated with feeding behavior, but for which exciting roles in social behavior have recently been demonstrated. This finding is particularly exciting as it supports our recent hypothesis that novel social behaviors may evolve by co-opting genes important in social behavior.

            Taken together, the project provides a number of important insights. First, this project has laid critical groundwork for exciting future work in poison frogs by me and others. Second, the project provides insights into the neural and molecular mechanisms important for parental care in amphibians specifically and vertebrates generally. Finally, this work addresses the fundamental question of whether the evolution of similar behaviors in different species relies on the same of different building blocks. In other words, does evolution tend to find the same ‘mechanistic solution’ for a given adaptive problem, or are neural systems flexible such that many solutions are possible? My findings here suggest that the same brain regions and molecules have been repeatedly targeted in the evolution of parental care. Identification of mechanisms universally important in parental care has implications for our understanding of the evolution of parental care and other social behaviors and provides important guidance for translational applications.

            In addition to the scientific pursuits of the project, I have been deeply engaged in outreach activities, with a focus on increasing diversity in STEM. Two high school teachers, four high school students (all female, two from groups underrepresented in STEM), and one undergraduate student (female, from a group underrepresented in STEM) have participated in research activities in the field and in the lab. Their activities in the lab have included data collection for the project and completion of independent projects. Both high school teachers accompanied us to our field sites in Ecuador where they undertook a project comparing ant diversity in distinct frog habitats. Under the supervision of the teachers, myself, and other lab members, samples collected in the field were processed by students in biology classes at two local, public high schools. I have also participated in public outreach events including the Bay Area Science Festival (~40,000 visitors of all ages annually) and NightLife at the California Academy of Sciences (when the museum is open to adults on the last Thursday of each month), and an open house during which first generation community college students are invited to visit Stanford and interact with researchers from STEM labs.
